It should be less than maximum temperature
"Total Population" should be greater than "Target Population"
Please enter a value between 0 to 42.
Please enter a value between 0 to 11.
Please enter a value between 0 to 42.
Please enter a value between 0 to 11.
If above selection is 'No' then this must be 'Yes'

bind.relevant: selected( /EVM_DVS_22082014_V2/E0_01/group_q1/E0_01a_A ,'yes') or selected( /EVM_DVS_22082014_V2/E0_01/group_q1/E0_01a_B ,'yes') or selected( /EVM_DVS_22082014_V2/E0_01/group_q1/E0_01a_C ,'yes') and selected( /EVM_DVS_22082014_V2/E0_01/group_q3/E0_03a_A ,'yes')

bind.jr:constraintMsg: Value should be positive and less than or equals to refrigeration unit
Value should be positive and less than or equals to the number of freezer rooms.
Value should be positive and less than or equals to the number of cold rooms
Value should be positive and less than or equals to the number of vaccine freezers and refrigerators
Value should be positive and less than or equal to total number of refrigerators and freezers present.
Value should be positive and less than or equal to total number of icepack/cool water pack units.
Value should be positive and less than or equals to session planned
Value should be positive and equal or less than issued.
Value should be positive and equal or less than issued.
Value should be positive and equal or less than issued.

input.label: Effective Vaccine Management Initiative
input.hint: EVM Assessment Tool for state vaccine store

select1.label: District:
L1 - Assessment Scope

input.label: Geo point
input.hint: Please ensure that co-ordinates are captured under clear sky.

upload.label: Image 1
upload.hint: Please ensure that the name of the facility is clearly visible in the image.

upload.label: Image 2
upload.hint: Please ensure that the name of the facility is clearly visible in the image.

input.label: L2.01 Supply Chain Levels - Lowest Distribution Level
L2.04 - Unique code for this facility:
L2.14 - Assessed records start date
input.hint: Assessed date refers to the period of review

input.label: L2.15 - Assessed records finish date
input.hint: Assessed date refers to the period of review

input.label: L3 - Permanently employed staff in the facility
input.hint: In this section, record the specified details about the permanent employees of the facility.

group.label: L3 - Permanently employed staff in the facility

input.label: Qualifications
input.hint: Specify level of education: e.g. technical college vocational qualification, university first degree etc.

input.label: Experience
input.hint: Record previous experience in the field of vaccine management. To be specified in Years and Months (if any)

input.label: Years in post
input.hint: Record duration in the current post. To be specified in Years and Months (if any)

group.label: E0 Complete these facility specific questions before continuing.

input.label: E0:01a What type of cold chain equipment is used in the store?

select1.label: A. Freezer room(s) and/or cold room(s) are used for storing vaccine?
B. Freezers and/or refrigerators are used for storing vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Including solar refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Freezer room(s), cold room(s), freezers or refrigerators are used for freezing icepacks or cooling cool water packs?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Select 'Yes' if there is equipment in the store used exclusively for freezing or cooling icepacks. Ignore fridge/freezers with icepack compartments or freezer rooms/cold rooms that are also used to store vaccine.

input.label: E0:03a What type of equipment is used to deliver and/or collect vaccine at this store?

select1.label: A. Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and/or other passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 'Other passive containers' includes insulated roll containers or palletized containers.

select1.label: B. Refrigerated vehicles?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: These may be used at primary and sub-national levels.

input.label: E0:04a What organization is responsible for vehicle operations at this store?

select1.label: A. Government agency
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 'Transport' means any type of vehicle, including motorcycles, cars, trucks, boats and aircraft.

select1.label: B. Parastatal, PPP or 3PL contractor
select1.hint: Guidance Note: PPP = public-private partnership. 3PL= third party logistics contractor. Official' transport is one or both of A and B

select1.label: C. There is no official transport at this store
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Official' transport is one or both of A and B

input.label: E0:05a Specify all transport types used for vaccine delivery or collection at this level.
input.hint: Guidance Note: List all transport types: government-operated, parastatal or private.

select1.label: A. Motorcycles
B. Cars, vans, trucks, refrigerated trucks and other road vehicles
C. Aircraft
D. Railway
E. Boat
F. Other

group.label: E2 All vaccines and diluents are stored within WHO-recommended temperature ranges.

select1.label: E2:03a Can the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) give the correct storage temperature range for each of the vaccines on the schedule?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Knowledge of correct storage temperatures is vital. If the respondent gives any incorrect answers, score 'No'. Note also: 1) If s/he says that freeze-dried vaccines should be stored at -20°C record this as 'Yes'. Current WHO advice is to store these vaccines at +2° to + 8°C, but storage at -20°C will not damage these vaccines. 2) If s/he say that freeze-dried vaccines packed with diluents can be stored at -20°C, this answer MUST be scored as 'No'. 3) At service point level, it is correct to say that all vaccines can be stored at +2° to +8°C

select1.label: E2:04a Do the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) know which vaccines on the schedule can be damaged by temperatures below 0°C?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: It is essential that respondents know which of the vaccines should not be exposed to temperatures below 0°C. It is not important that they know the precise freezing temperature of each of these vaccines.

select1.label: E2:05a Has the storekeeper received classroom, or on-the-job, training in how to look after vaccines?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Training should cover the following minimum topics: 1) correct storage temperatures; 2) vaccines damaged by freezing; 3) vaccines which can be frozen; 4) vaccines which must be frozen; 5) VVM reading; 6) shake test; 7) temperature monitoring using the range of available devices; 8) storage of diluents; 9) how to arrange vaccines in cold rooms, freezer rooms, refrigerators and freezers; 10) icepack conditioning; 11) cold box/vaccine carrier packing.

select1.label: E2:07a If there is refrigeration equipment, Is there a complete set of manual temperature records for each and every cold room, freezer room, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: This question applies all in health facilities with active refrigeration. It does not apply in health facilities where cold boxes or vaccine carriers are used to store vaccine temporarily. Manual records are necessary because this is the only way to be sure that temperatures are checked at least twice a day. 'Complete' means that there should be no missing' record sheets or electronic temperature traces and that the entire review period should be covered for each appliance.

select1.label: E2:11a If there is refrigeration equipment, Have temperature records been kept in a safe place for at least three years?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Countries should be encouraged to retain such records for tracing purposes. If records are not available for three years, review the records kept since the immunization programme adopted EVSM or EVM.

input.label: E2:12a If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature review checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: There must be a written record of these reviews which identifies problems and records actions taken. A verbal assurance is not sufficient.

select1.label: A. Are temperature records formally reviewed at least once a month in order to identify temperature excursions and their causes?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check whether records are reviewed and recorded. 'Excursions' are temperatures below +2°C or above +8°C for cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators, and above -5°C for freezer rooms and vaccine freezers.

select1.label: B. Have correct remedial actions been taken?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Interview the responsible person. Discuss and evaluate remedial actions taken.

group.label: E3 Cold storage, dry storage and transport capacity is sufficient to accommodate all vaccines and supplies needed for the programme.

input.label: E3:01a If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary level) or the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the +2°C to + 8°C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the +2°C to + 8°C store(s) in liters or m³.
B. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Note: The store capacity, taking account of utilisation factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
E. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)

E3:09a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule or outreach session size data, establish whether coolant capacity is sufficient to meet maximum demand levels
input.hint: Guidance Note: Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations. There must be sufficient freezing or cooling capacity to produce an adequate flow of icepacks/chilled water.

select1.label: A. Is there sufficient freezing or cooling capacity to meet maximum demand? .
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Icepack freezing or cooling may sometimes take place in another facility. If this is the case, the capacity of the other facility needs to be checked.

select1.label: B. Is there sufficient storage capacity for icepacks/chilled water packs storage to meet peak demand? .
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Peak demand' is the maximum weight of icepacks/chilled water packs required in a day.

input.label: E3:10a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether there are sufficient passive containers to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Check total vaccine storage capacity of available passive containers and compare against delivery schedule. If containers are always supplied by the receiving store this question is not applicable here but must be assessed at the next level down in the supply chain.

select1.label: A. Does this store stock passive containers for delivery and/or collection?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Answer 'Y' if the store keeps a stock of passive containers. If delivery and collection dates are staggered, the same containers may be used for both purposes.

select1.label: B. Are there sufficient passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If some containers are in use, check the container inventory to establish how many there should be.

input.label: E3:11a If there is refrigeration equipment. Vaccine store contingency planning checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Note:Contingency plans are context-specific, but should include the following minimum elements: 1) Identify the major sources of risk (e.g. power failure, flood, earthquake, etc.). 2) Prepare a written contingency plan. 3) Post emergency contact details on the noticeboard in the vaccine store. 4) Staff must know that the universal safe storage temperature for ALL vaccines in an emergency is +2°C to +8°C.

select1.label: A. Is there a satisfactory SOP which sets out a contingency plan in the event of equipment failure or other emergency?
select1.hint: 5) Identify at least two alternative cold storage locations. Inspect them to make sure they are large enough, well-managed, and can maintain correct temperatures.

select1.label: B. Are emergency contact details posted in the vaccine store?
select1.hint: 6) Ensure that there is a written agreement with the selected emergency providers. If payment will be required, make sure that this can be funded.

select1.label: C. Do staff know what to do in the event of an emergency?
select1.hint: 7) Regularly rehearse the contingency plan with store staff and the emergency providers.

group.label: E4 Buildings, cold chain equipment and transport systems enable the vaccine and consumables supply chain to function well

input.label: E4:03a Vaccine store or health facility building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Note: Vaccine store' in this context includes service point health facilities.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine store building suitable for the climate?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof free of leaks?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Roof leaks': Check for damp stains on ceilings.

select1.label: C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage?
D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)? .
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Reasonably level': The floor should not be visibly sloping and it should be smooth enough for small wheeled pallet trucks.

select1.label: F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have they been tested in the past 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date. Fire extinguishers are unlikely to be found in small health facilities, so enter 'n/a'.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Satisfactory' means that wiring, circuit breakers, electrical sockets and light fittings are in good condition and securely fixed in place. All circuits should be properly earthed. In a full inspection the earthing of sockets can be checked with a ring main tester. If there are any doubts, a professional inspection should be carried out. Service point facilities may have no electricity. If this is the case, score 'n/a'.

select1.label: H. Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)?
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
K. Is the heating system working?

input.label: E4:13a If there are refrigerators and/or freezers Vaccine freezer/refrigerator checklist.

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine freezers comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine freezers have continuous temperature recorders?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Continuous temperature recording in freezers is only mandatory at primary store level.

select1.label: C. Do vaccine freezers have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: All freezers should have a stem or dial thermometer.

select1.label: D. Do all vaccine refrigerators comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site. PIS and PQS pre-qualified equipment should have a sticker to show the climate rating.

select1.label: E. Are all ice-lined refrigerators fitted with the correct vaccine storage baskets?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: ILRs must always be fitted with baskets so that vaccine does not come into contact with the bottom or walls of the unit because this can freeze vaccine.

select1.label: F. Do all vaccine refrigerators have continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers or freeze indicators?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers (Fridge Tag type) are essential at primary level. Refrigerator loggers are desirable at SN, LD and SP levels.

select1.label: G. Do all vaccine refrigerators have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
H. Where applicable, are there sufficient reserve supplies of kerosene and/or gas?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 'Sufficient' reserve supplies means at least one spare Jerry Can of kerosene or at least one spare full gas bottle.

select1.label: J. Where applicable, is kerosene or gas always available?
K. Cold climates only. Do vaccine refrigerators EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?

input.label: E4:14a If there is refrigeration equipment Inspect refrigeration equipment
A. How many refrigeration units are there (dual CR and FR units count as 2, refrigerators and freezers count as 1 each)?
B. How many of these are CFC-free?
E4:15a Standby generator.
input.hint: Guidance Note: There should always be a standby generator at the primary store unless mains electricity is completely reliable and/or has a backup supply from a separate transformer. The same requirement applies at sub-national stores equipped with cold rooms. Generators are not required in small sub-national stores, lowest distribution level and service point stores where ice-lined refrigerators are used and there is at least 8 hours electricity per day. Generators are also not required where kerosene, gas or solar refrigerators are used or where a health facility uses cold boxes or vaccine carriers for storing vaccine.

select1.label: A. Is a generator required at this store?
B. Is a standby generator installed?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If a generator is installed but is not required then the generator questions are switched off and need not be answered.

input.label: E4:16a If a generator is required and installed, standby generator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: The sidebar tool can be used to help with these calculations.

select1.label: A. Is the generator in working order?
B. Can the generator start all the connected equipment in the vaccine store? .
select1.hint: Guidance Note: The starting load for a refrigeration compressor is much higher than the running load. Ask for a demonstration to prove that the generator is able to cope with the combined starting load of all connected refrigeration units. Well-designed systems may have 'smart switching' which reduces the starting load by automatically phasing in the individual refrigeration units.

select1.label: C. Is the fuel tank large enough?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 72 hours continuous running is recommended, but this is context-dependent. If power cuts are short and/or fuel is readily available, a smaller capacity will be acceptable. The way to assess this is as follows: 1) Establish the longest power cut experienced during the review period. 2) Check the generator fuel consumption in liters per hour. 3) Check the capacity of the fuel tank. If tank capacity/consumption per hour is less than the longest power cut then the tank capacity is too small.

select1.label: D. Are there sufficient reserve supplies of fuel?
E. Is the generator in a secure compound?
E4:17a Is the voltage fluctuation sufficiently severe to require voltage regulation equipment?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Voltage regulation equipment on all refrigeration equipment is essential if voltage fluctuations exceed ±15%. Obtain information from an electrical engineer, or from the local supply company.

input.label: E4:18a If voltage regulation is required, voltage regulator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: If there is no refrigeration equipment in a particular category - e.g. 'freezer room', enter 0 for the equipment number and 0 for the voltage regulator number.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator?
input.hint: Guidance Note: There may be a single central voltage regulator for the vaccine store or some sharing arrangement across multiple appliances. In this case score on the basis that every piece of equipment has a regulator and make a note in the comment box.

input.label: C. How many cold rooms are there?
D. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
E. How many vaccine freezers and refrigerators are there?
F. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
input.hint: Note: Solar refrigerators do not require voltage regulators. Absorption refrigerators require a different type of voltage regulator to those used for compression refrigerators. This needs to be checked during the inspection.

select1.label: E4:21a Are telecommunications links working?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Telecommunications links include telephone, internet and radio. At least one of these must be working well.

input.label: E4:22a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store, General vehicle checklist (includes refrigerated vehicles).
input.hint: Guidance Note: This checklist is written with road vehicles in mind. Some programmes may own and operate boats. If this situation is encountered, evaluate boats using this indicator. If transport is provided by a parastatal or private sector contractor try to inspect their vehicles, especially if refrigerated vehicles are used.

select1.label: A. Is every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, in good mechanical condition?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Ignore vehicles that are scheduled for disposal.

select1.label: B. Does every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, have its own user logbook?
C. Does every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, have an up to date maintenance and service record (including a record of refrigeration unit servicing where applicable)?
A. If passive containers are used, do passive containers used at this level comply with WHO specifications?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Passive containers include cold boxes, vaccine carriers and palletiZed or roll containers. Identify products by using the PQS or PIS catalogue.

select1.label: B. If refrigerated vehicles are used, are the disposable cartons or reusable crates used to transport vaccine fit for purpose?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: No standard set. Use judgment to assess quality. Most important is the way in which cartons or crates are packed and restrained.

group.label: E5 Maintenance of buildings, cold chain equipment and vehicles is satisfactory.

input.label: E5:01a Planned preventive maintenance checklist for buildings.
input.hint: Guidance Note: This question is primarily about planned preventive maintenance (PPM). However, it is possible that the building is in good condition because it is being informally maintained. 01 : C covers this option.

select1.label: A. Is there a written multi-year planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If the score to question A is 'N' then the score for Question B must also be 'N'. PPM activities should be monitored and recorded.

select1.label: C. Is there visual evidence that maintenance is taking place?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If an effective maintenance programme is in place, the building should be in good condition. Indicators of poor building maintenance include broken light bulbs, leaks and damp stains, blocked drains, flaking paintwork, etc. See answers to E4:04a.

input.label: E5:02a If there is refrigeration equipment, Planned preventive maintenance checklist for refrigeration equipment.
input.hint: Guidance Note: In this context, 'Planned Preventive Maintenance (PPM)' is as set out in the cold chain equipment manufacturers' service manuals. Both the need for and the timing of PPM can be foreseen.

select1.label: A. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: PPM should be recorded in a maintenance record book or worksheet.

select1.label: C. Is somebody assigned to carry out routine maintenance?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: A permanent member of the facility staff must be formally assigned to carry out the tasks below. They should not be left to ancillary staff such as cleaners.

select1.label: D. Is there evidence that cold rooms/refrigerators/ freezers have recently been cleaned and defrosted?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check for excessive ice accumulation on evaporator units or the inside lining. Ice accumulation or condensation along the panel joints in cold rooms and freezer rooms is a sign that panel joints are leaking or poorly designed.

select1.label: E. Is there evidence that kerosene refrigerator wicks have been trimmed and chimneys cleaned?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Frequent trimming and replacement of wicks in kerosene refrigerators is absolutely essential. Chimneys also need to be cleaned regularly, especially if kerosene quality is poor.

select1.label: F. Is there evidence that solar refrigerator battery electrolyte has been checked and solar panels cleaned?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Some flooded batteries are not sealed and require regular checking of electrolyte levels and topping up with battery acid. All solar panels should be cleaned from time to time to maintain efficiency. This is particularly important in dusty areas and in countries where there is snow.

select1.label: G. Are all solar panels completely unshaded by buildings, trees and overhead cables?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Shading seriously degrades solar panel performance. Shading problems can increase over the years following the original installation as trees grow, new buildings are built and new overhead cables are erected.

input.label: E5:03a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store, transport maintenance and overhaul checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: This indicator only applies to government-operated vehicles

select1.label: A. Are vehicles maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's service manual?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: The maintenance regime in the manufacturer's service manual must be followed.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the service manual is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Documentary evidence' may be a service log book or a stamp in the service manual supplied with the vehicle.

select1.label: C. Is there a written planned overhaul programme?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Overhaul' means the dismantling or replacement of major components, such as clutch linings, engines, transmissions, etc. The timing may vary between similar vehicles, but the need can be foreseen.

select1.label: D. Is there documentary evidence that the overhaul programme is being followed?

input.label: E5:05a If vaccine is stored at the facility AND there are refrigerators/freezers, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer maintenance checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Include all vaccine refrigerators and freezers in the store, unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many vaccine refrigerators and freezers are there (all types, including solar)?
input.hint: Guidance Note: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Guidance Note: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box. With kerosene units, check that the burner has been assembled correctly.

input.label: E5:06a If there are dedicated icepack freezers/cool water pack coolers, maintenance checklist for freezer rooms, cold rooms, freezers and refrigerators only used for freezing icepacks or cooling cool water packs.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Include all units in the store unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many icepack/cool water pack units are there?
input.hint: Guidance Note: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Guidance Note: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box.

input.label: E5:07a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store, transport availability checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: As a general rule, under EVM recommendations, distribution vehicles should not be out of operation for more than 7 days. This question helps establish whether transport availability is high or low.

input.label: A. During the review period, how many vaccine collections, distributions or outreach immunization sessions were planned?
input.hint: Guidance Note: Outreach immunization sessions' in this context means sessions that required a motorcycle, car or 4WD.

input.label: B. How many were cancelled or seriously delayed because of mechanical failure in the vehicle fleet?
input.hint: Guidance Note: Cancelled' means that the distribution or immunization session did not occur during the planned working week. 'Vehicle' includes motorcycles, cars, 4WD, trucks and small boats. Air and rail links (if used) are assumed to be outside the programme's control.

group.label: E6 Stock management systems and procedures are effective.

select1.label: E6:01a Is a computerized stock control system in use?

input.label: E6:02a If computerized stock control is used, computerized stock control checklist.

select1.label: A. Is the software fit for purpose?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 'Fit for purpose' means that it can handle the full range of vaccines and commodities, has sufficient data capacity for the country's needs, and records the minimum data set.

select1.label: B. Is the software package supported by the software developer?
C. Is there up-to-date anti-virus software on the computer?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Anti-virus software is essential.

select1.label: D. Has the storekeeper received training in its use?
E. Is the computer suitable for its purpose and in working order?
F. Is the printer in working order and supplied with paper?
G. Is the computer equipment connected to the standby generator?
H. Are stock records printed out and filed as a permanent record at least once a month?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Paper records are needed as a backup and for quality assurance and review purposes.

select1.label: J: Are stock records backed up at least once a week?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Backup should be on a flash drive, secondary hard drive, CD/DVD or on a secure web-based backup site. Ideally the device should be kept off site.

select1.label: E6:03a Are all vaccine arrivals and vaccine dispatches recorded and stock balances updated within one working day of the transaction?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: The practice of batch processing arrival and delivery slips should be discouraged because it leads to out of date stock records.

input.label: E6:04a Do the stock records record the following information for all vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Arrival. Accurately record incoming vaccines, diluents, and other consumables.

select1.label: A. Type of vaccine
B. Vaccine presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Vaccine manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each vaccine batch
G. VVM status where applicable
H. Location in the store

input.label: E6:05a Do the stock records record the following information for all diluents that are packed separately from the vaccine to which they belong.

select1.label: A. Type of diluent
B. Diluent presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Diluent manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each batch
G. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Note: A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and in health facilities.

select1.label: E6:07a Are vaccine requisition forms used for ordering and receiving vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: See model SOP on requisitioning for guidance on good practice. Assess content of existing form(s) against the content of the model forms.

select1.label: E6:08a Is there an effective pre-delivery, or pre-collection, notification system in place?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 'Effective' means that the system is understood and used by the receiving stores and that deliveries or collections are reliably made on or near a day that has been arranged well in advance.

select1.label: E6:09a Do stock records and/or stock in hand demonstrate that vaccine is issued according to the 'earliest-expiry-first-out' (EEFO) principle?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Unless VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure, vaccines should always be issued in EEFO order. Health worker use of EEFO is covered by question E8:09. In PR, SN and LD stores, the stock records should contain the data needed to demonstrate compliance. Otherwise physically check the stock. In health facilities it may be easier to check the stock in hand.

select1.label: E6:10a Can the storekeeper make exceptions to the EEFO rule (e.g. because of VVM status)?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure whilst early-dated stock is still at Stage 1, the heat-exposed later-dated stock should generally be issued first.

select1.label: E6:13a Does the issuing store have a completed arrival voucher for every delivery which took place during the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Use judgment. If the review period has just ended, the arrival slip for recent deliveries may not yet have been received by the issuing store. There may be other legitimate reasons for missing forms. The important point is that the incoming goods must be checked and the form must be signed by the receiving store.

select1.label: E6:14a Does a representative sample of these completed arrival sections indicate that arrival checks were carried out correctly?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: As with temperature records, suspiciously 'correct' forms may conceal lax practices. If vaccines are put in quarantine for any reason, these vaccines should be ignored.

input.label: E6:15a If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for management of damaged or expired stock.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the stock control system designed to record vaccine and diluent wastage due to expiry, freezing or heat-exposure?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If vaccine has to be discarded, any associated diluent must also be discarded. Failure to do this can lead to a stockpile of 'orphaned' diluent.

select1.label: B. If 'yes', do the records show that the system is being used?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If the stock records show that there have been no losses during the review period, ask the storekeeper to confirm whether or not this is true.

select1.label: C. Do staff know that expired and damaged vaccine should be clearly labelled and stored out of the cold chain until final disposal?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Damaged vaccine must be clearly labelled and stored outside the cold chain to prevent it being issued in error.

select1.label: D. If 'yes', is there evidence that the procedure is followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check that there is no damaged/expired vaccine in the store.

input.label: E6:16a If there is a functioning system for recording damaged or expired vaccine, select a freeze-sensitive vaccine. Establish how many doses have been discarded during the review period due to freezing or exposure to high temperature.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Carry out this check even if the storekeeper reports that no vaccine has been lost.

select1.label: A. Select a sample vaccine

input.label: B. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine issued during the review period.
C. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine discarded because of incorrect storage temperatures.
input.hint: Guidance Note: This indicator can only be assessed if stock records are accurate, informative and truthful. If there is no method to record vaccine damage, the score is 0.

select1.label: E6:17a Are disposal facilities and procedures in accordance with WHO and/or national norms?
E6:18a Have records of discarded vaccine been kept for at least three years, or, if for a lesser period, since the immunization programme adopted the EVSM or EVM?
E6:19a Are internal reviews of the vaccine loss/damage records carried out at least twice a year?

input.label: E6:20a Assess stock level policy.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Use the stock records to assess whether the store held excessive and/or insufficient stock during the review period.

select1.label: A. Is a maximum stock level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: A maximum stock level should be set to control over-stocking. Overstocking makes store management difficult and increases the risk of expiry.

select1.label: B. Is a reorder level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: A reorder level is needed to take account of delivery lead-time so that safety stocks are not breached

select1.label: C. Is a safety stock level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: A safety stock level needs to be set to reduce the risk of stockouts.

select1.label: D. During the review period, did the stock of each and every vaccine remain within its EVM recommended maximum?
select1.hint: Note: The EVM maximum recommended stock level for each vaccine is its defined maximum stock level plus 10%.

select1.label: E. During the review period, did the stock of each and every vaccine remain within its EVM recommended minimum?
select1.hint: Note: The EVM maximum recommended stock level for each vaccine is its defined maximum stock level plus 10%.

input.label: E6:21a Check stockouts and related events during the review period.
input.hint: Guidance Note: If no records are available, interview the storekeeper and make a judgment.

select1.label: A. Were vaccine stocks sufficient throughout the review period (no stockouts)?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: A stockout occurs when the demand or requirement for an item cannot be fulfilled from the currently available inventory. It does not necessarily mean that there is zero stock. Cases may occur where there is a stockout, but this does not affect deliveries because a new vaccine arrival occurs before the next delivery has to be made. Question B covers this situation.

select1.label: B. Was the facility always able to supply all the lower level stores?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Deliveries to lower level stores are not applicable at health facility level.

input.label: E6:22a Physical inventory frequency checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Note: Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

input.label: A. Enter the planned vaccine supply period, in months
B. Enter number of recorded physical counts of vaccine stocks carried out during the 12 month review period
input.hint: Guidance Note: Primary stores should carry out a physical count at least 4 times a year. Lower level stores and health facilities should carry out a count at the time of each incoming delivery. The scoring logic assumes this frequency.

select1.label: E6:23a If vaccine is stored at the facility, choose a sample freeze-dried vaccine and diluent. Enter name.
select1.hint: Guidance Note: This question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers. The following checks are carried out.

input.label: A. Carry out a physical count of the sample vaccine. Enter number of doses counted.
B. Carry out a physical count of the sample diluent. Enter number of doses counted.
input.hint: 1) If the diluent count differs from the vaccine count by >±1% a 'Mismatch' message appears. Otherwise a 'Match' message appears.

input.label: C. Check stock records for sample vaccine. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock.
input.hint: 2) If the vaccine stock records = the vaccine count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: D. Check stock records for sample diluent. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock.
input.hint: 3) If the diluent stock records = the diluent count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: E. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly AND vaccine and diluent quantities are within 1% of one another (see results).
input.hint: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 0 and 4.

input.label: E6:24a If consumables are held in this store, choose a sample consumable.

select1.label: A. Choose a sample consumable. Enter name.

input.label: B. Carry out a physical count of the sample consumable. Enter number of items counted:
C. Check stock records for sample consumable. Enter number of items recorded as currently in stock:
D. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 4 and 0 for mismatches.
input.hint: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem.

input.label: E6:25a If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for vaccine storage arrangements.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine stock secure?
B. Are contents labels fixed to all cold chain equipment indicating vaccine type, lot no. and expiry date?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check for labels on the lid of feezers and refrigerators, or on the edge of the shelves in freezer rooms and cold rooms. Score 'n/a' where labelling is not needed. Labels are not required at health facility level unless there are several refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Are vaccines correctly stored?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: No freeze-sensitive vaccines stored close to cold room evaporators, stored close to the ice lining in ILRs or stored close to the evaporator plate of service point refrigerators. No vaccines should be kept in the door shelves of domestic refrigerators.

select1.label: D. Is vaccine laid out in EEFO order, by type and by lot number?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Ask which vaccines of a particular type are going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: E. Is the vaccine store clean, dry and pest-free?

input.label: E6:26a If consumables are held in this store, checklist for dry storage arrangements.

select1.label: A. Are dry goods secure?
B. Are dry goods correctly stored?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: 'Correct' means that stocks should be neatly stacked on pallets so that they are accessible and are not affected by floor washing.

select1.label: C. Are dry goods laid out in an orderly fashion and in EEFO order where applicable?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Syringes have expiry dates and must therefore be organized in EEFO order. Ask which stock is going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: D. Is the dry store clean, dry and pest-free?
E6:27a Are the records secure?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Records should be stored in lockable filing cabinets.

group.label: E7 - Distribution between each level in the supply chain is effective.

select1.label: E7:01a During the review period, did the issuing store send a distribution programme to each receiving store setting out dates for the delivery and/or collection of vaccines?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Throughout this section, the issuing store is the store which is being assessed.

input.label: E7:02a If a distribution programme exists, assess actual deliveries/collections against the programme.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Actual deliveries must be within 80% to 120% of planned deliveries. If no distribution programme exists, the score is 0.

input.label: A. Enter number of deliveries/collections (to all receiving stores) that were scheduled during the review period?
B. Record the number of deliveries/collections made during the review period.
E7:03a If a distribution programme exists, assess the timeliness of a sample of deliveries/ collections.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Sample period is context dependent. For example, if deliveries are made four times a year over two week periods, the chosen sample should be one of these two week periods.

input.label: A. How many deliveries/collections were scheduled during the sample period?
B. How many deliveries/collections actually took place during the sample period?
input.hint: Scoring: Algorithm ensures that score is always <1 if actual deliveries/ collections do not match the number scheduled.

select1.label: E7:04a If a distribution programme exists, during the review period, was there a reporting system which monitored actual vaccine distributions and compared these with planned distributions?

input.label: E7:05a Assess number of short shipments during the review period and check if they were followed up and corrected.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Compare requisition quantities with actual delivery quantities. Question the storekeeper on the actions s/he has taken to reduce the impact of short shipments when they occur.

select1.label: A. Were there any short shipments?

input.label: B. If there were short shipments, evaluate the effectiveness with which short shipments were managed.
input.hint: [Score on a scale of 0-4].

input.label: E7:06a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used, assess knowledge of coolant preparation and packing of cold boxes, vaccine carriers and other passive containers.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Whether a systematic temperature monitoring, or journey profiling, study has been carried out. Coolant preparation includes icepack conditioning, preparation of cool water packs and preparation of coolant for palletized or wheeled passive containers.

select1.label: A. Icepack conditioning or cooling of chilled water packs is in accordance with WHO guidelines?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: For palletized or wheeled containers, follow the manufacturer's instructions.

select1.label: B. Is packing in accordance with appliance labelling or SOP?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and other passive containers are designed to suit a particular size of icepack. Sometimes the correct size is not available. In such circumstances it is essential that store staff know what to do.

select1.label: E7:08a Cold climates only. Do staff know how to prevent vaccine freezing during transport?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Refer to SOP on freeze prevention for details.

select1.label: E7:09a Are freeze indicators required for the transport of freeze-sensitive vaccines?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Freeze indicators are NOT required if cool water packs are always used in passive containers and there is no risk of freezing in winter months. Freeze indicators MAY be required when vaccine is transported in refrigerated vehicles with poor temperature control or limited monitoring equipment. Freeze indicators ARE required when freeze-sensitive vaccines are packed with frozen ice packs, even if these have been conditioned. They are also recommended in very cold climates where warm water packs are needed to prevent vaccine freezing during transport.

input.label: E7_10a If freeze indicators are required, were freeze indicators packed with deliveries of freeze-sensitive vaccines during the review period? Scoring: Score on a scale of 0-4 where 4 indicates that freeze indicators were used on all deliveries and 0 indicates that they were never used.
input.hint: Guidance Note: If freeze indicators are used, there must be an effective zero-reporting system to record the state of the freeze indicator on arrival at the receiving store. Scoring: Score on a scale of 0-4 where 4 indicates that freeze indicators were used on all deliveries and 0 indicates that they were never used.

input.label: E7:11a Select a one month sample of issue vouchers.
input.hint: Guidance Note: If no system is in place, leave the questions unanswered. Note "absence of system" in notes box. Scoring algorithm ensures that only returned and fully completed vouchers count towards the score.

input.label: A. How many vouchers were issued by the issuing store?
B. How many arrival sections of the sampled issue vouchers have been returned to the issuing store?

select1.label: C.1 Does the returned vouchers record VVM status?

input.label: C.2 How many of the returned vouchers record VVM status ?
D. If freeze indicators are required, how many of these vouchers also record freeze indicator status?
input.hint: Scoring algorithm ensures that only returned and fully completed vouchers count towards the score.

input.label: E7:12a Assess vaccine losses caused by freezing or heat exposure during transport from the issuing store
input.hint: Guidance Note: This is a difficult indicator to assess, unless the stock records are transparent and honest. 100% score is achieved if there are no losses. If losses occurred and damaged vaccine was replaced in a 'reasonable' time, the score is 50%.

select1.label: A. The EVM target is a total loss of less than 1%. (Score Y if this target was achieved, otherwise score N).
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Reasonable period' depends upon the level in the cold chain and the established supply interval and the extent of the vaccine damage. The country should have a clear policy to cover this and the assessment should be made against this policy.

select1.label: B. If 1% loss target was exceeded. Was the damaged vaccine replaced within a reasonable period of notification to the issuing store?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If there is no fixed policy, use judgment. For example, at service point level, if the set supply interval is 4 weeks, then 2 weeks would be reasonable. If the supply interval is 2 weeks, then one week would be reasonable.

group.label: E8 - Appropriate vaccine management policies are adopted and implemented.

input.label: E8:01a Knowledge of the shake test
input.hint: Guidance Note: This question is not applicable at health facility level in situations where there is no refrigerator

select1.label: A. Does the storekeeper or health worker know how to conduct the shake test?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check knowledge against the Shake test learning guide

select1.label: B. Does the storekeeper or health worker know when to conduct the shake test?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check knowledge against the Shake test learning guide

select1.label: C. Has the storekeeper of health worker carried out a shake test in the last 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Only score n/a if you are sure that there were no events in the review period that required a shake test.

select1.label: E8:05a Are written instructions on the use of VVMs, such as posters and stickers, available to storekeepers and health workers?
E8:06a Do storekeepers/health workers know how to read VVMs?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Use dummy VVMs and/or sticker samples to check knowledge. To score 'Y', all those responsible in the facility must answer correctly.

input.label: E8:12a Review the periodic immunization reports and/or any other reporting forms that are used to monitor vaccine wastage. [Score 0 if there is no reporting. Score on a scale of 1-4 if formal reporting exists. Use commentary to elaborate].
input.hint: Guidance Note: At national level this question should be addressed to the EPI Manager. At lower level stores wastage rates may not be calculated. However, the information needed for the calculation should be collected and reported up the supply chain. For example, number of children immunized, doses used and doses lost, destroyed or expired.

input.label: E8:13a Wastage calculation checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Note: At national level this question should be addressed to the EPI Manager.

select1.label: A. Do you calculate wastage rates for each vaccine?
B. Is there a standard form used to record wastage?
C. Is there a complete set of wastage records for the review period?
D. Are these data used to monitor vaccine management performance?
E8:14a Does the facility receive regular supportive supervision?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Ask staff when the last supervisory visit took place and how regular these visits are. Answer yes if the level of support is suitable, taking account of the general knowledge of the facility staff.

group.label: E9 - Information systems and supportive management functions are satisfactory.

select1.label: E9:01a Is there a Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) manual?
E9:04a Does the facility have a copy of the SOP manual?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Check that relevant SOPs are available. For example there is no need to have an SOP for looking after cold rooms at lowest distribution level.

input.label: E9:07a Checklist for vaccine needs forecasting.
input.hint: Guidance Note: Use one of the options described in the Mid-level Management training series. Namely: 1) At primary and sub-national levels: Target population or previous consumption data. 2) At service point level: Session size. Check to ensure that there is compatibility/convergence with the method used in developing the country's comprehensive multi-year plan (cMYP).

select1.label: A. Is a standard method used to estimate annual vaccine need?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Standard method' means the UNIICEF vaccine forecasting tool or equivalent. 'Evidence-based' means that data have been systematically collected - for example national population census, updated as necessary.

select1.label: B. Is evidence-based target population data used in the calculation?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Calculations can be based on target population data and assumed vaccine wastage rates, but it is much better to use evidence-based wastage data collected from the field.

select1.label: C. Is evidence-based coverage data used in the calculation?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Coverage data will generally be taken from the routine reporting system. Ideally these data should be verified by periodic coverage surveys.

select1.label: D. Is evidence-based vaccine wastage data used in the calculation?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: Calculations can be based on target population data, coverage data and assumed vaccine wastage rates, but it is much better to use evidence-based wastage data collected from the field.

select1.label: E9:08a Is an evidence-based method used to forecast need for syringes and safety boxes?
